title: Silent Weight: Young Adult Mental Health Crisis at Home

patientInfo.name: Daniel Thompson
patientInfo.location: Small rented unit in a suburban Brisbane street; patient seated on couch, curtains closed, low lighting
patientInfo.initialPresentation: QAS dispatched for a welfare check after Daniel texted a friend saying he was "overwhelmed and can’t do this anymore." On arrival, Daniel appears withdrawn, tearful, and anxious. No immediate physical injuries noted.

performanceMetrics.name: Support Needs Identified
performanceMetrics.description: Recognition of social and community care needs

performanceMetrics.name: Risk Assessment
performanceMetrics.description: Identification of safety concerns and clinical risks

performanceMetrics.name: Safety Planning
performanceMetrics.description: Creation of safety nets and follow-up advice

performanceMetrics.name: Care Coordination
performanceMetrics.description: Arrangement of referrals and handover to services

performanceMetrics.name: Care Pathway Selection
performanceMetrics.description: Choosing the appropriate disposition and pathway

q1.text: What is your most appropriate initial approach on making contact with Daniel?
q1.context: Daniel avoids eye contact and speaks quietly.

answers.text: Introduce yourself, explain your role, ask permission to sit down, and acknowledge that this may be a difficult time for him.
answers.feedback: A trauma-informed, respectful introduction helps reduce perceived threat and establishes trust and rapport, which are critical foundations for mental health assessment within LARU.

answers.text: Begin asking direct questions about why QAS was called and whether he intends to harm himself.
answers.feedback: Jumping straight into risk questioning without rapport can increase defensiveness and reduce engagement, undermining effective assessment.

answers.text: Tell Daniel you need to assess him quickly so you can decide whether to take him to hospital.
answers.feedback: This task-focused approach may escalate anxiety and reinforces fear of loss of control, which is counterproductive in mental health care.

q2.text: Which initial clinical assessment is most appropriate at this stage?
q2.context: Daniel reports poor sleep, low appetite, and ongoing anxiety.

answers.text: Conduct a full set of vital signs and a brief physical assessment while explaining why this is important.
answers.feedback: Mental health presentations still require medical screening to exclude physiological contributors, consistent with LARU principles.

answers.text: Skip physical assessment and focus only on Daniel’s emotions and thoughts.
answers.feedback: Failing to assess physical health risks missing contributing or compounding medical issues.

q3.text: How should you explore Daniel’s mental health history?
q3.context: Vital signs: HR 96, BP 128/78, RR 18, SpO₂ 98%, BGL 5.4 mmol/L.

answers.text: Use open-ended questions about previous mental health diagnoses, treatments, and recent stressors.
answers.feedback: Open-ended questioning supports rapport and yields richer clinical information.

answers.text: Ask only whether he has ever been diagnosed with depression or anxiety.
answers.feedback: This narrow approach may miss relevant context such as recent triggers or treatment adherence.

answers.text: Avoid discussing history to prevent upsetting him.
answers.feedback: Avoidance limits understanding of risk and undermines safe decision-making.

q4.text: Daniel says, "Sometimes I wish I wouldn’t wake up." What is your best response?
q4.context: He becomes tearful but continues talking.

answers.text: Acknowledge his feelings and ask directly about thoughts of suicide or self-harm.
answers.feedback: Direct, compassionate questioning is essential for accurate suicide risk assessment and does not increase risk.

answers.text: Reassure him that many people feel this way and move on to another topic.
answers.feedback: Normalising without assessment risks missing active suicidal ideation.

answers.text: Document the comment but avoid asking further questions about suicide.
answers.feedback: Failure to explore suicidal thoughts represents a serious gap in care.

q5.text: Daniel discloses passive suicidal thoughts but denies a current plan. What should you assess next?
q5.context: He states he feels isolated since losing his job.

answers.text: Assess protective factors, supports, substance use, and access to means.
answers.feedback: A comprehensive risk formulation includes both risk and protective factors.

answers.text: Accept his denial of a plan and assume risk is low.
answers.feedback: Risk exists on a spectrum and requires broader exploration.

q6.text: Which action best addresses Daniel’s immediate safety?
q6.context: He lives alone; no weapons noted, but medications are present in the unit.

answers.text: Collaboratively discuss ways to reduce immediate risks, including safe storage of medications.
answers.feedback: Collaborative safety planning empowers the patient and aligns with LARU best practice.

answers.text: Confiscate medications without discussion.
answers.feedback: Unilateral actions can damage trust and engagement.

answers.text: Do nothing as there is no active plan.
answers.feedback: Missed opportunity to reduce foreseeable risk.

q7.text: How do you assess Daniel’s capacity to consent to a LARU-based care pathway?
q7.context: Daniel is calm, coherent, and able to explain his situation.

answers.text: Confirm he understands options, risks, benefits, and can communicate a clear choice.
answers.feedback: Capacity assessment supports ethical and lawful decision-making.

answers.text: Assume he lacks capacity due to suicidal thoughts.
answers.feedback: Suicidal ideation alone does not equal lack of capacity.

q8.text: Which referral option best aligns with LARU principles at this point?
q8.context: Daniel is open to support and prefers to avoid ED if safe.

answers.text: Arrange referral to the local Acute Care Team / crisis mental health service with safety planning.
answers.feedback: Using community-based crisis services aligns with LARU’s aim to provide the right care in the right place.

answers.text: Transport Daniel to ED by default.
answers.feedback: Automatic ED transport may be unnecessary and contrary to patient-centred care.

q9.text: What follow-up advice should be included before leaving Daniel at home?
q9.context: The crisis team will make contact within 2 hours.

answers.text: Provide written and verbal safety advice, crisis numbers, and clear instructions on when to re-contact QAS.
answers.feedback: Clear follow-up and escalation advice strengthens safety nets.

answers.text: Assume the crisis team will cover all follow-up needs.
answers.feedback: Gaps in advice can leave patients vulnerable during transition periods.

q10.text: How should you complete handover and documentation for this case?
q10.context: Care is being transitioned to community mental health services.

answers.text: Provide a detailed clinical handover including risk factors, protective factors, and agreed safety plan.
answers.feedback: Comprehensive handover ensures continuity of care and shared understanding of risk.

answers.text: Document minimal details as the patient is not being transported.
answers.feedback: Incomplete documentation risks fragmentation of care.

summary.text: Daniel remains at home with an agreed safety plan and timely follow-up by the crisis mental health team. He reports feeling heard and supported, with reduced immediate distress. Appropriate use of the LARU framework avoids unnecessary ED transport while maintaining safety.
keyLearningPoints: Trauma-informed communication is foundational to effective mental health care.
Comprehensive suicide risk assessment includes both risk and protective factors.
LARU pathways support safe, patient-centred alternatives to emergency department transport.
